content.text: Bash ping Command - Send Request to Network Hosts
Using the ping Command
The ping command is used to send ICMP ECHO_REQUEST to network hosts.
content.html: The ping command is used to send ICMP ECHO_REQUEST to network hosts.

content.text: It's a useful tool for checking network connectivity and diagnosing network issues.
content.html: It's a useful tool for checking network connectivity and diagnosing network issues.

content.text: Basic Usage
To ping a host, use ping hostname :
content.html: To ping a host, use ping hostname:

content.code:
ping
google.com
Pinging google.com [142.250.74.110] with 32 bytes of data:
Reply from 142.250.74.110: bytes=32 time=79ms TTL=57
Reply from 142.250.74.110: bytes=32 time=52ms TTL=57
Reply from 142.250.74.110: bytes=32 time=48ms TTL=57
Reply from 142.250.74.110: bytes=32 time=38ms TTL=57

Ping statistics for 142.250.74.110:
Packets: Sent = 4, Received = 4, Lost = 0 (0% loss),
Approximate round trip times in milli-seconds:
Minimum = 38ms, Maximum = 79ms, Average = 54ms
content.code_html:
ping google.com
Pinging google.com [142.250.74.110] with 32 bytes of data:
Reply from 142.250.74.110: bytes=32 time=79ms TTL=57
Reply from 142.250.74.110: bytes=32 time=52ms TTL=57
Reply from 142.250.74.110: bytes=32 time=48ms TTL=57
Reply from 142.250.74.110: bytes=32 time=38ms TTL=57

Ping statistics for 142.250.74.110:
    Packets: Sent = 4, Received = 4, Lost = 0 (0% loss),
Approximate round trip times in milli-seconds:
    Minimum = 38ms, Maximum = 79ms, Average = 54ms

content.text: Options
The ping command has options to change how it works:
content.html: The ping command has options to change how it works:

content.text: Send a Specific Number of Ping Requests
The -c option allows you to send a specific number of ping requests.
content.html: The -c option allows you to send a specific number of ping requests.

content.text: This is useful for limiting the number of packets sent.
content.html: This is useful for limiting the number of packets sent.

content.code:
ping
-c
4
google.com
PING google.com (172.217.14.206): 56 data bytes
64 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=0 ttl=118 time=14.5 ms
64 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=1 ttl=118 time=14.2 ms
64 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=2 ttl=118 time=14.3 ms
64 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=3 ttl=118 time=14.4 ms

--- google.com ping statistics ---
4 packets transmitted, 4 packets received, 0.0% packet loss
round-trip min/avg/max/stddev = 14.2/14.3/14.5/0.1 ms
content.code_html:
ping -c 4 google.com
PING google.com (172.217.14.206): 56 data bytes
64 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=0 ttl=118 time=14.5 ms
64 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=1 ttl=118 time=14.2 ms
64 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=2 ttl=118 time=14.3 ms
64 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=3 ttl=118 time=14.4 ms

--- google.com ping statistics ---
4 packets transmitted, 4 packets received, 0.0% packet loss
round-trip min/avg/max/stddev = 14.2/14.3/14.5/0.1 ms

content.text: Understanding Ping Results
The output of the ping command provides several key pieces of information:
content.html: The output of the ping command provides several key pieces of information:

content.text: In the example above:
Wait a Specific Number of Seconds Between Sending Each Packet
The -i option allows you to wait a specific number of seconds between sending each packet.
content.html: The -i option allows you to wait a specific number of seconds between sending each packet.

content.text: This can be useful for reducing network traffic when using ping .
content.html: This can be useful for reducing network traffic when using ping.

content.code:
ping
-i
2
google.com
PING google.com (172.217.14.206): 56 data bytes
64 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=0 ttl=118 time=14.5 ms
64 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=1 ttl=118 time=14.2 ms

--- google.com ping statistics ---
2 packets transmitted, 2 packets received, 0.0% packet loss
round-trip min/avg/max/stddev = 14.2/14.3/14.5/0.1 ms
content.code_html:
ping -i 2 google.com
PING google.com (172.217.14.206): 56 data bytes
64 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=0 ttl=118 time=14.5 ms
64 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=1 ttl=118 time=14.2 ms

--- google.com ping statistics ---
2 packets transmitted, 2 packets received, 0.0% packet loss
round-trip min/avg/max/stddev = 14.2/14.3/14.5/0.1 ms

content.text: Set the IP Time to Live (TTL)
The -t option allows you to set the IP Time to Live (TTL).
content.html: The -t option allows you to set the IP Time to Live (TTL).

content.text: This determines the maximum number of hops a packet can take before being discarded.
content.html: This determines the maximum number of hops a packet can take before being discarded.

content.code:
ping
-t
64
google.com
PING google.com (172.217.14.206): 56 data bytes
64 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=0 ttl=64 time=14.5 ms

--- google.com ping statistics ---
1 packets transmitted, 1 packets received, 0.0% packet loss
round-trip min/avg/max/stddev = 14.5/14.5/14.5/0.0 ms
content.code_html:
ping -t 64 google.com
PING google.com (172.217.14.206): 56 data bytes
64 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=0 ttl=64 time=14.5 ms

--- google.com ping statistics ---
1 packets transmitted, 1 packets received, 0.0% packet loss
round-trip min/avg/max/stddev = 14.5/14.5/14.5/0.0 ms

content.text: Quiet Output
The -q option enables quiet output, only showing the summary of the ping results.
content.html: The -q option enables quiet output, only showing the summary of the ping results.

content.text: This is useful for scripts or when you only need the final statistics.
content.html: This is useful for scripts or when you only need the final statistics.

content.code:
ping
-c
4
-q google.com
--- google.com ping statistics ---
4 packets transmitted, 4 packets received, 0.0% packet loss
round-trip min/avg/max/stddev = 14.2/14.3/14.5/0.1 ms
content.code_html:
ping -c 4 -q google.com
--- google.com ping statistics ---
4 packets transmitted, 4 packets received, 0.0% packet loss
round-trip min/avg/max/stddev = 14.2/14.3/14.5/0.1 ms

content.text: Specify Data Bytes
The -s option allows you to specify the number of data bytes to be sent.
content.html: The -s option allows you to specify the number of data bytes to be sent.

content.text: This can be useful for testing network performance with different packet sizes.
content.html: This can be useful for testing network performance with different packet sizes.

content.code:
ping
-s
128
google.com
PING google.com (172.217.14.206): 128 data bytes
136 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=0 ttl=118 time=14.5 ms

--- google.com ping statistics ---
1 packets transmitted, 1 packets received, 0.0% packet loss
round-trip min/avg/max/stddev = 14.5/14.5/14.5/0.0 ms
content.code_html:
ping -s 128 google.com
PING google.com (172.217.14.206): 128 data bytes
136 bytes from 172.217.14.206: icmp_seq=0 ttl=118 time=14.5 ms

--- google.com ping statistics ---
1 packets transmitted, 1 packets received, 0.0% packet loss
round-trip min/avg/max/stddev = 14.5/14.5/14.5/0.0 ms
